commentBody: It is 10:08pm and I am‚Ä¶ done with the Friday puzzle? A personal best by a mile!
Way too easy for a Friday!  Romped through it in 5:19, less than half my usual time for a late week puzzle.  It's fun to have such a quick solve now and then, though, so I'm not complaining!
Sleepless in the English Midlands and delighted by the fresh, young fill in this puzzle.

Wish came true, Malaika! A PB at 8:15. A fun jaunt! As a lover of DARKACADEMIA, I was excited to see it referenced (although my speed is more the literary version, rather than the clothing, etc.). 
Love it or hate it, The Secret History is my favorite book, and one of the most referenced examples of DARKACADEMIA.
Super easy Friday for me - personal best by an absolute mile. I'm so sad it's over. I always want a puzzle to last but now I have to wait for tomorrow!
Odd: For the second day in a row, I have been unable to find any error in my solve, yet no confirmation from the software.
Great fill, but less a Friday than a Tuesday with some long entries. And the constructor was going for a Saturday!? I think everyone is getting a personal best on this one.
A new record for me too. Maybe a little harder for the older generation but for me Gossip Girl, Minecraft (and Ore), Goat & Avengers were all quick fills.

For the people posting their times, I will say this: Seeing the times of fast solvers is disheartening to many developing solvers, and for that reason is considered gauche in many corners of the crossword world.
Very enjoyable puzzle with some fresh clues and fill, if a bit less challenging than an average Friday. Well done!

This was another good one! I love a Friday that‚Äôs in my wheelhouse. Allowed me to significantly best my average. Thanks for such a fun puzzle, Malaika! Great clues and answers.
Y‚Äôall have a fantastic Friday!

Good fill.

Good clueing ... for a Tuesday.

3/10

I had a lot of help with this one.  How To Be An ANTIRACIST was a question on Jeopardy earlier this week, and my grandson‚Äôs fascination with Minecraft has given me lots of knowledge about that game.  DARKACADEMIA was new to me and the last fill to be completed.  

I thought it was cute to work in the dreaded Oreo via OREOCOOKIE.  

Liner notes for SEASHANTY was an A+. Way haul away, we‚Äôll haul away Joe.

This has got to be my fastest/best Friday ever, less than half my average time and without a single clue or lookup. (Usually I need help past Wednesday.)
There will probably be a lot of complaints that this was too easy, but sometimes maybe that‚Äôs what we need.

Malaika produces some high quality puzzles, and always fair and interesting.  As I just said to VF, I ran through this one fairly quickly, but might have shaved about five more seconds off my time if I hadn't hesitated a decent bit at the last thing I put in, double checking all the crosses to be sure it was right.

That answer was 61A: IKEAS.  

The clue was [They're the subject of more than 200 million catalogs a year].  There are so many less clunky ways to clue a plural IKEAS.  Maybe [Stores in Brooklyn, Paramus and 52
 other US locations.]  Or [Stores in New York and Oslo].

But all 200 million catalogs are the subject of just one IKEA, the overall business.  The clue, despite its included meganumber, is not set for a plural answer.

At the very least, it's unnecessarily clunky.

Maybe it was changed by an editor.
Far too easy for a Friday.  I expect much chewier.  Looking forward to Saturday puzzle.  ü§û
This was a Friday? 7:49, fastest ever for a Friday, and fastest solve since Monday this week

We haven‚Äôt had a nit about parasites lately (ever?) so I‚Äôm here to point out that the *cause* of sleeping sickness is Trypanosoma brucei, rather than the tsetse fly which is just the vector.  

Yeah, I know, the clue is still okay.

Just need to nit a nit once or twice a year!

Thank you for your attention to this matter.
This might have been the easiest Friday puzzle. I solved it half my average time, and didn‚Äôt have to look up anything.
Finished in Monday time I feel like a genius, but wish it were harder
I was thrilled with my time and charmed when I read your constructor notes wishing us personal bests. I hope you have an incredible weekend!
I‚Äôm surprised that some people have solve times of 5 to 6 minutes. Even when I instantly know every answer, my fingers can‚Äôt work fast enough to achieve such a fast solve.
Come on. This would have been a nice Wednesday or a tough Tuesday.
I came to see if it was easy for other people, after the more than difficult Wed and Thu this week.  I guess it was easy for many of us, with Oreo cookies and few proper names.

Definitely a PB by a long shot for me as well. It would have been faster, but I entered OREO Crumbs before COOKIE. It was quickly corrected by the crosses. After the first two across answers which I popped in without a second thought, I moved onto the downs and went all the way through the downs which is not my usual pattern to solve. Joan Rivers interviewed ELVIRA on the Tonight Show years ago - so funny!! https://youtu.be/vLhqptKfbSE?si=PTf0lrf4HMj82GTE Thank you, Malaika. Happy Friday, everyone!
Good Wednesday puzzle

Loved the fill on this and found it to be a little more accessible for a Gen Z solver :) loved Dark Academia, Gossip Girl, and Minecraft. 

My 4th gold star on a Friday and 2nd ever 5-day streak. Fingers crossed to get a 6 day streak for the first time tomorrow! It has been fun to slowly feel like I‚Äôm getting better at these.
I too found this ridiculously easy for Friday, but not a PB - in fact, 3 other Fridays this year went faster (Jan. 31, April 11 and 18)

Seemed more like a Tuesday or a maybe even a Monday.  
Very disappointed.
The editing team should have made this a Monday or Tuesday. Fun, but way too easy for a Friday.
20A was a gimme, thanks to Jenny Jackson‚Äôs ‚ÄúPineapple Street.‚Äù

Here's my SEASHANTY:

Yo Ho, as Friday's go,
The answers came like a Wednesday flow.

Have to agree with those on easy street. Nothing gave me much pause and anything I didn‚Äôt know pretty much off the bat (DARKACADEMIA) came quickly on crosses. Heck I even knew the Beyonc√© song and Gossip Girl. 
My biggest letdown is when the first entry in a themeless is a gimme. I‚Äôm not saying it always has to be the most difficult entry, but at least take a stab at clueing it cleverly or obtusely. Even if you never heard of PALEODIET in real life, you know it from crosswords (it‚Äôs the only way PALEO gets clued these days) so why make the clue so obvious? That‚Äôs true of most of the grid except for SEASHANTY which I liked. It‚Äôs too bad because this was a very well constructed grid which could have been made much more challenging and interesting.
A couple of weird clues‚ÄîSteve already mentioned IKEAS, I was wondering why we care that Simone Biles wears a GOAT on on her neckla‚Ä¶oh just got it! GOAT ‚ÄîGreatest of All Time. I take it back that one was actually pretty clever. Should‚Äôve been mentioned in the column.
Oh well we‚Äôll probably be slammed tomorrow.

Interesting take on the HALO in the new Dan Brown / Robert Langdon book - the light not emanating outward but transmitting inward. Some interesting concepts in his latest but a far cry from some of the others, IMO.  I know they‚Äôre all formulaic but Angels and Demons and Da Vinci Code were good fun. 

This Friday puzzle is similar to a Dan Brown book. Didn‚Äôt stretch the limits of the brain but an enjoyable way to pass the time.

When I got to the 3/4 mark in 11 minutes I was thinking "This is the easiest Friday of all time".

Then I got stuck for so long on the bottom left corner.  It still seems super easy by Friday standards.  But GOSSIP GIRL, OREO COOKIE, FEEDER TEAM and DARK ACADEMIA had me really struggling.  For a while I had GO GET EM instead of GO FETCH.  Then I found GO FETCH, doubted it, tried other things.

Then crossings like ICEDAM, RIALS, SODONE.  Still very easy by Friday standards but that corner of the puzzle felt like Friday.

I knew what to expect from the comments and they didn't disappoint üòÇ

Well, I enjoyed it. What can I say... I don't mind having an easier ride once in a while. üòé

Why in the world I'd insist on "German" Demokratische Republik rather than "Deutsche Demokratische Republik", I cannot say?

But 'tis a blemish I carry to this forum.

I really have to watch "Toy Story" someday if I want to keep doing these crosswords.
Id like to think Im getting better but in reality it was just a very easy Friday.
Just be my Wednesday average on a Friday. After some recent challenges, I'll take it.
Zeit, die Erbsen zu z√§hlen. Die Initialen f√ºr das alte Ostdeutschland w√§ren DDR. In English it's GDR üôÑ
If it makes anyone feel better, my snail pace like time was 16min, mainly due to going down a dead end with the answer "no no no" instead of "so done!"  Or maybe it's too close to my sleepy time..

Sad to say for all of you, CHAOS, 10A, opens up one of my favorite subjects.  

James Gleick is an amazing writer of science fact, and I've read his book "Chaos" at least twice.  It is perfectly written and covers such an astonishing topic.  A brand new branch of mathematics having surfaced and sprouting in our lifetimes.

I can't do the subject justice here, but I can say you really don't need to understand classical mathematics to really get a gut-level feeling for Chaos and Complexity.  And the colored versions of the Mandelbrot set are breathtaking.  

God's fingerprint.

Reading Glieck's "Chaos" changed my life a little.  I began seeing things I hadn't seen before.

Shortly after I left academia I was writing monkey level computer code and the subject of the movie "American Beauty" came up, in our group, which drew a lot of derision.  Particularly the scene in which the Wes Bentley character films a long sequence of a piece of paper caught in the swirl of winds, twisting in a corner of a building.

They laughed and laughed at how "artsy" it was.  

All I could think was that I was seeing a Strange Attractor in real life, and I was mesmerized.

I never told them about that.

A Friday that was made for me. Just for me.  I knew every single answer.  Felt like a Monday! Played like a Monday!!!

Yayyyyy!

I know many will be disappointed, but let me have this.
I am shocked how easy I found this Friday puzzle. 1/3 of my usual time. Faster than my average for Mondays!

I can only hope that the post I made on CHAOS, for which I got an email with a link that pulls it up, will eventually be viewable here.

I have no idea why it's not, but I don't ask those kinds of questions anylonger.

Was breezy except I had GDR and haven't seen or thought about Toy Story in decades, so thought Sig might have been the name. Should've questioned that when I thought I'd solved it and got the keep trying message! Ha. Had I known I was wrong, it would've been a nattick-- what's the term for that? Not-it?
This was infinitely easier than that rabbit/duck monstrosity from Wednesday

I tried to follow the link to the story about fruit streets in Brooklyn, https://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1993/12/05/issue.html But on my iPhone it links to the front page of the pertinent issue, and it‚Äôs very unwieldy to scroll through the pages‚Ä¶ has anyone found which page the article is on?

I agree that the bulk of this puzzle was probably on the EZ side.

But, I'd like to point out that the easiest puzzles can still have a seriously difficult square.

I should have known 26D was DDR, no gDR, even though, as I see now, GDR is a valid entry for the clue, especially since the clue itself did not indicate (I don't think) that the answer was in German.

Couple that with being openly hostile to most Pixar films, there was no way I was going to be finding that mistake.

Too easy for Friday. 17 min. I kinda feel cheated. Wed & Thurs this week both much more difficult. This could have been a Wednesday and no one would have questioned it. Going for 100 day streak tomorrow, so now I have to think the Xword gods will throw something hellish at us...
I enjoyed solving this puzzle so much that I started slowing down because I didn‚Äôt want it to end! (and still ended up with a 6 minute solve time)

I solved this in 15 minutes, which is 20% faster than my Wednesday average. I enjoyed the solve, but I would have preferred it earlier in the week. Many of the clues were simply way too obvious for Friday.

That being said, I was unfamiliar with some of the fill, and thus had to make a few guesses: DARK ACADEMIA (I've never heard of it), FEEDER TEAM (ditto, but I guess I get the name), ICE DAMS (what are those? The clue and its answer don't match anything I know from our winters. I've seen dams, sort of, created by ice floe, but I wouldn't describe those as clued today).

For once I knew much of the trivia and proper names. I saw my first DAVID Attenborough documentary as a kid in the 1980s and have loved the guy since then. He's like the Jesus and Captain Picard of naturalists ü§©. I think I owe my fascination with and respect for nature to him, to a large extent.

Have to add my congratulations to Deb on her pending retirement from the NYT.  I'm an old guy (will be 67 in December) from the midwest and the NYT crossword has been a daily task since I retired at the beginning of 2023.   Reading the wordplay is part of my quotidian routine following the solve. Im struck, not just by Deb's passion for all things crossword, but her consistently positive attitude, sense of humor, and empathetic mien.  Wishes for a long and healthy retirement that allows you to do all those things that a full time job doesn't.

I solved that in 7 minutes which is almost 20 minutes faster than my usual Friday time‚Ä¶almost finished it with the across clues alone. Must‚Äôve been a lucky day for my knowledge base! Sad though because I love to suffer through a Friday.

I‚Äôm as bad as everyone else at complaining, but I‚Äôm surprised at so many comments on how easy this one is for a Friday. Take the win & move on, IMO.
My time was 13:09, 1:39 faster than my Friday average. That was on an iPad in the NY Times Games app, where I‚Äôm a 1-fingered typist.
I only looked up the bee genus (didn‚Äôt know the last letter), the ‚ÄúToy Story‚Äù clue (it‚Äôs been too long, & I didn‚Äôt know if the crossing answer would use the German or English acronym‚Äîthat clue was written in English, so English was my 1st pick), the gymnast charm (don‚Äôt watch woman‚Äôs gymnastics), & the Nobelist name (but I had the 1st letter & knew it was Russian, so I could have gotten it without Google).
I left the 1st letter of cellular data plan blank, as DNA & RNA are used interchangeably here & often incorrectly.
A fun puzzle today, & I look forward to a challenge tomorrow.

I think both had a lot to do with the relatively low number of black squares. There were so many crosses to every answer that there was always a way in, for even the more challenging clues. Thanks, Malaika, for showing me a good time while also making me feel Friday smart!

I like the fact that the NYT does not treat the relatively difficulty level of the days of the week as a hard and fast rule, although I notice this is a favorite topic for kvetching on here. There are only two themeless puzzles a week. It‚Äôs nice that some are easy and some are hard. Part of the fun for me is not knowing the exact difficulty level and therefore having to consider a wider range of possible answers. Tomorrow may take me 20 minutes or an hour and a half.  That‚Äôs POG. (?).

I learned about Antoni Gaudi when I was still in my teens. I was reading William Gibson's book "Count Zero" and got to the scene that takes place on a bench in a computer simulation of Park G√ºell, was curious about the place, and since I was in a library at the time, found a book that included many illustrations of Gaudi's architecture and became a little obsessed.

So, fifty years or so later, I finally made it to Barcelona, and was actually sitting on that very bench. And about ten feet away from me was a perfectly coiffed, perfectly dressed young woman. She set up her ring light, attached her phone to her selfie stick, got her shot, then left. She got her proof that she was there, although in a sense she never really was.

I never thought I would live in a time when narcissism is seen as a virtue.
Thank you Malaika for a delightful puzzle! Breezy and fun. My favorite clue in a long time was Liner notes. Guffaw worthy!

Someone pointed out in the comments that students now aren't learning to touch type. I think that's really sad. I learned in "junior high school" & I find it really useful. It was an elective. I was going to take stenography after that, but that never happened. 

I learned at university there are certain skills that are easier for young people to learn--& I think touch typing is one of them. Think of foreign language. The best time for children to learn a foreign language is when they're learning the first language. They don't use grammar books, verb charts, vocabulary lists, etc. They just pick it up like a sponge.

When people reach puberty, that kind of learning dries up somewhat. Some synapses in the brain disappear! I heard an interview with a famous pianist who said that all the pieces he learned when he was young, he memorized. After puberty--not so much.

Many people know an immigrant family: the kids sound like native speakers of English; the older ones will never lose some foreignisms--in pronunciation and/or syntax.

I know a young woman who just finished her B.S. pre-med w/ great grades. Now she's working on preparing to take the MCATs for medical school. She told me the MCATs don't allow the use of calculators. Now she has to learn all over how to do the simplest math without her device. How much is 10% of 150? She'll practice & figure out those types of problems now. It's sad that students don't have this basic facility with math problems without "smart" phones.

We lost something culturally special with the passing of album liner notes.  Reading personal insight on the music while listening was a wonderful ritual that gave engaging perspective, and often some interesting behind the scenes insider info.  For example, I never knew the piano at Abbey Road was so incurably out of tune that Lennon had to perform the vocal on ‚ÄúImagine‚Äù while submerged in a tank of tomato aspic to get the pitches to match.  Or that the drum intro on ‚Äú50 Ways To Leave Your Lover‚Äù was actually Richard Nixon shaking his jowls into an SM57.  Often what we think of a song on the radio can be tempered dramatically by learning more about the artistic intentions of the songwriter. For example, without the pithy and erudite revelations found in Andre The Giant‚Äôs liner notes for Joni Mitchell‚Äôs magnum opus ‚ÄúLadies of the Canyon,‚Äù I would have never known that ‚ÄúBig Yellow Taxi‚Äù was not a metaphorical comment on the civilizational destruction of natural beauty, but rather a cry for help from desperate woman in the depths of a toxic obsession with livery cabs.  Or that Stravinsky‚Äôs ‚ÄúRite of Spring‚Äù was really about a colonoscopy gone wrong.

@Outside Editor

I've said this before...it's like par in golf.  Top golfers can usually shoot par or at least come close.  Most golfers come nowhere near it.  But it's still a useful tool for all golfers, for measuring the relative difficulty of holes.

Xwstats info is the same.  I, an experienced solver, routinely fall within a close radius of the stated median time, often beating it.  I can figure out if I found it harder than others did, or easier.

Less experienced solvers can still use it to gauge how hard it was compared to other puzzles.  The absolute numbers can be ignored if they depress you.  

But I'll bet that, given time, those slower solvers will eventually move closer to the range shown on the site.

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Acually, Steve, I think par in golf isn't a measure of a holes difficulty, but of its length.  Par, is the number of shots allowed to put the ball on the green, and then two putts.  There can be some very easy holes, and some very difficult holes that have the same par value.

@Dan

How to say this gently...

As a beer league softball player, would you find it disheartening that Shohei Ohtani can hit a 100-mph fastball into the upper deck of Dodger Stadium?

As a weekend duffer, would it bother you that Tiger Woods can shoot a 72 on any given day?  (Or at least could at one time?)

Why would you stomp on the joy of someone who just set a personal best and wants to tell the world?

I know, they could say they got a personal best without giving the time, but why?  Because you're not there yet?

I personally don't post my exact times anymore, not that I'm obsessed with them anyway.  I've gotten fast without necessarily aiming for it after more than 40 years of solving.  Back then, there was newsprint and pen(cil), and no help column, and certainly no comment section.  The learning curve was extremely slow.  

Now, you can get that help to improve your game and move up the ranks infinitely faster.  The column and comments are resources that I think some newer solvers take for granted.  But with these resources, come people who express their experiences in a multitude of ways.

Why silence their form of expression because you think it's gauche?  For every person who disapproves of time posting, there's probably another who's fine with it, and a third one who doesn't care one way or the other.

Don't like time postings?  Ignore them.

Putting it another way, let's say you could enter the answers orally, taking the time spent entering the answers down to practically zero.  If you can complete a really easy Monday puzzle that way in about 3 minutes, you could still solve that fast (or within mere seconds of it) if you can read the next clue while entering each answer.  I was saying that it can be done physically, not that anyone was capable of doing it.

Most younger people these days have never learned to touch type.  That would make it harder to improve past maybe 5-6 minutes.

And all this is predicated that the solver is good enough to spit out the answers to practically every clue nearly instantaneously.  Which is a big assumption.

I've been warned about ice dams since moving to Minnesota.

Say your roof is covered in snow, and that the insulation for your house is such that the higher points of the roof are warm enough to melt snow, but the eaves are not.

The snow will melt, but be trapped by the eave snow.  This traps liquid water against a roof with no where to go.  Not a good situation.

Some people rake their roofs in the winter here.  I've done it, but only under extreme duress.

Could not agree more about David Attenborough.  The dulcet voice of Mother Nature.

@Francis

Thank you! Climate change has changed our winters, but we still get heavy snow quite often, and my family home has a sloping, eaved roof, yet I've never heard of this. I can see how it would be a problem though. I wonder, maybe even more snow than we get in Mazovia is needed for this to materialize? Or have we just been inexplicably spared ice dams for 30 years of owning the house? Interesting. The only related issue we've had was when snow, ice melt and ice accumulated over the only non-sloping section of the roof, over the antechamber. My father and I had to climb up there and remove that mess several times, as the roof would start to leak.

@Andrzej

I suspect that every so often conditions are just right for an ice dam to ruin a house's roof.

It only has to happen a few times to make everyone sit up and take notice.

One defense is better insulation, preventing the roof from getting hot enough to melt the snow.  But I can still imagine the strong winter solar radiation causing melts on some winter days.

So I don't really know how common they are, how specific they are to certain parts of the world, or how our slopes affect this. 

I do think that as the years have gone by, northern roofs are probably less steep than they used to be.

@Francis In my area many have installed electric cables on the outside of their roofs to melt the ice to prevent the dams. They are most common in Cape cod styles houses because of they often lack insulation on the top floor.

I had a small collection of albums back in the day. I played them on one of those plastic portable stereos that closed up and had a handle...it was a mustard yellow. I remember learning of a new album release, and anxiously awaiting the moment to buy it, a fresh platter of vinyl, shiny, no dust, no scratches and would shut myself up in my tiny bedroom to hear it for the first time. While taking in the music I loved so much, I'd read the album cover, often featuring original art work, to find out all the players: backup singers, musicians, writers, contributors of all types, and of course, the lyrics. I loved knowing  all those details. (Yes, I'm a movie credits reader too.) When music went to cassette tapes, sometimes you might find a little booklet stuffed in the case. Then came CDs and downloads, so just the music pretty much.  Over the years and multiple moves my little collection was lost, but I am grateful I can find it all through streaming, and new music too, but the depth and richness with which I experienced it back then, is missed.
